frame.name: FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Speaker</fen> expresses a <fen>Message</fen> serving to assess or denying a <fen>Proposition</fen> (or something a <fen>Past_speaker</fen> said). The <fen>Addressee</fen> is semantically understood, but cannot be expressed locally for the LUs in this frame. The key aspect is that the content of the <fen>Proposition</fen> is either the contrary of the <fen>Message</fen> (for negating LUs) or at least can be substantially different from the <fen>Message</fen>, which serves as support to assess the <fen>Proposition</fen>. For some of the LUs, the <fen>Past_speaker</fen> can be expressed instead of the <fen>Proposition</fen>. <ex>FR-EX:<fex name="Spkr">La ministre</fex> <t>nie</t> que <fex name="Proposition">le pays est entré en récession</fex>.</ex> <ex>FR-EX:<fex name="Spkr">La ministre</fex> a <t>démenti</t> <fex name="Proposition">l'existence d'un tel plan</fex>.</ex>
<ex></ex> Distinctions with other frames: <ex></ex> ≠ <frframe>FR_Statement-manner-noise</frframe> : for the LUs in FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition, the Message and the Proposition are either the opposite, or can substantially differ. This results in a key difference when the LUs are used in direct or indirect speech: in indirect speech, for FR_Statement-manner-noise LUs, the clausal complement is what the Speaker is purported to have said, whereas for the FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition LUs, it is either the opposite (e.g. to deny) or at least it can substantially differ from it (e.g. to confirm), the Message then serving as support for the Proposition. Compare: <ex>FR-EX:<fex name="Spkr">Il</fex> <t>renchérit</t> que <fex name="Message">c'était pas le moment en plus</fex>. [FR_Statement-manner-noise] </ex> <ex>FR-EX:<fex name="Spkr">Il</fex> <t>nie</t> qu' <fex name="Proposition">un tel outil ait pu exister à cette période</fex>. [FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition]</ex> <ex>FR-EX: " <fex name="Message">Désormais, il semble que tout ce qui est secret est bon à publier</fex>, <t>confirme</t> <fex name="Spkr">un journaliste</fex> . [FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition, message serves to confirm a prior discourse]</ex> <ex>FR-EX: " <fex name="Message">Il n'y a effectivement plus de soupe</fex>, <t>confirme</t> <fex name="Spkr">le serveur</fex> . [FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition, depending on context, message and content coincide or not]</ex>
<ex></ex> ≠ <frframe>FR_Taking_sides</frframe> : in FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition, all the LUs necessarily evoke a verbal communication, whereas in FR_Taking_sides the LUs include this possibility. Further, in FR_Expressing_truth_of_proposition, what is expressed concerns the veracity of the Proposition, whereas in FR_Taking_sides it concerns its legitimacy. <ex></ex>
<ex></ex>
<asf>Relation to fndata-1.5</asf> : French equivalents of some LUs from the Statement frame were moved to this new frame. </def-root>

FE.name: Proposition
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Proposition</fen> whose truth or falseness the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to assess by uttering his <fen>Message</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Message
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Message</fen> communicated by the <fen>Speaker</fen>, serving to assess the truth or falseness of the <fen>Proposition</fen>. </def-root>

FE.name: Speaker
FE.definition:
<def-root>The individual or body that expresses the <fen>Message</fen>, serving to assess or deny the <fen>Proposition</fen>.
</def-root>

FE.name: Past_speaker
FE.definition: <def-root>The individual or body who previously expressed the <fen>Proposition</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Medium
FE.definition: <def-root>The written or spoken material that contains the message. <ex><fex name="Medium">The panel</fex> denied that ....</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Addressee
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Addressee</fen> is the person to whom the <fen>Message</fen> is communicated. <ex>Evelyn <t>confirmed</t> that information <fex name="Add">to me</fex>.</ex> </def-root>
